title: 111_hr3550
content: The Act is titled the "Senior Investor Protections Enhancement Act of 2009" and includes definitions for various terms. The "Senior Investor Protections Enhancement Act of 2009" defines "senior" as an individual aged 62 or older and specifies the securities laws it encompasses. Amendments are made to the Securities Act of 1933, Securities Exchange Act of 1934, and Investment Company Act of 1940 to include this definition. Amendments to the Investment Company Act of 1940 and Investment Advisers Act of 1940 define "senior" as an individual aged 62 or older. Enhanced penalties for violations of Securities Act of 1933. Enhanced penalties for violations of Securities Act of 1933 include a special rule for seniors, allowing the Commission to impose a civil penalty of up to $50,000 for each violation directed towards or committed against a senior. The Commission may impose a civil penalty of up to $50,000 for each violation committed against a senior. SEC. 4. ENHANCED PENALTIES FOR VIOLATIONS OF SECURITIES ACT OF 1934. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to include enhanced civil penalties for violations directed towards seniors, allowing the Commission to impose a penalty of up to $50,000 for each violation. Additionally, willful violations towards seniors may result in further penalties under the amended section. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 now allows the Commission to impose a civil penalty of up to $50,000 for violations directed towards seniors. Enhanced penalties for violations of the Investment Company Act of 1940 are specified in Section 5. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to include enhanced penalties for willful violations directed towards seniors, allowing for civil penalties of up to $50,000 per violation. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to allow for civil penalties of up to $50,000 for each violation directed towards seniors. ENHANCED PENALTIES FOR VIOLATIONS OF INVESTMENT ADVISERS ACT OF 1940. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to impose higher civil penalties for willful violations directed towards seniors, with a maximum penalty of $50,000 per violation. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to allow the Commission to impose a civil penalty of up to $50,000 for each violation directed towards seniors. Directive to the United States Sentencing Commission. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and amend the Federal sentencing guidelines to ensure appropriate punishment for violations of securities laws against seniors. This includes applying specific guidelines to offenses involving senior victims, maintaining consistency with other directives, making necessary changes, and meeting sentencing purposes. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and amend the Federal sentencing guidelines to ensure appropriate punishment for violations of securities laws against seniors, in order to adequately meet the purposes of sentencing set forth in section 3553(a)(2) of title 18, United States Code.
